data.title: Civil War Washington, D.C.
data.meta_description: Last Sunday night, my sister, my wife, and I watched Washington's 4th of July  fireworks from a hill on Ft. Myers that affords a sweeping vi...
data.text:
Ft. Whipple was located on a ridge along Arlington Heights rising 290 feet above the Potomac River.

It had a commanding of the rolling Virginia countryside to the west from which an enemy might approach Washington. :In an era in before environmental impact studies, Union efforts to establish clear fields fire resulted in extensive deforestation along Arlington Heights. The fort's water needs were provided by an onsite spring.

(US Army Corps of Engineers)

Ft. Whipple (highlighted in yellow) and several other forts of the Arlington Line superimposed on a modern road map. Ft. Whipple was a "bastioned quadrelateral work" designed to support the line of lunettes lining Arlington Heights. Ft. Whipple was also intended to provide additional firepower in support of Fort Corcoran, rendering practicable the temporary holding of it even should the two works in its front fall, and thus further protecting the Aqueduct Bridge, located near where the Key Bridge is today and one of three bridges into Washington from Virginia.
